translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty
The Second Chapter
The Discussion of Non-knowing
“Is there non-knowing of an Arahant?”
“Yes.”

original: Atthi arahato avijjā avijjogho avijjāyogo avijjānusayo avijjāpariyuṭṭhānaṁ avijjāsaṁyojanaṁ avijjānīvaraṇanti?
analyzed: atthi arahataḥ avijjā avijjā oghaḥ avijjā yogaḥ avijjā anusayaḥ avijjā pariyuṭṭhānam avijjā sayojanam avijjā nīvaraṇanti
translated: “Is there ignorance, a flood of ignorance, a yoke of ignorance, a latent tendency to ignorance, a covering of ignorance, a bondage of ignorance, an impediment of ignorance in an Arahant?”
“That cannot be said.”

original: Natthi arahato avijjā avijjogho avijjāyogo avijjānusayo avijjāpariyuṭṭhānaṁ avijjāsaṁyojanaṁ avijjānīvaraṇanti?
analyzed: natthi arahataḥ avijjā avijjā oghaḥ avijjā yogaḥ avijjā anusayaḥ avijjā pariyuṭṭhānam avijjā sayojanam avijjā nīvaraṇanti
translated: “Is there no ignorance, no flood of ignorance, no yoke of ignorance, no latent tendency to ignorance, no covering of ignorance, no bondage of ignorance, no impediment of ignorance in an Arahant?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci natthi arahato avijjā avijjogho avijjāyogo avijjānusayo avijjāpariyuṭṭhānaṁ avijjāsaṁyojanaṁ avijjānīvaraṇaṁ, no ca vata re vattabbe—🔽“atthi arahato aññāṇan”ti.
analyzed: āmantā  hañci natthi arahataḥ avijjā avijjā oghaḥ avijjā yogaḥ avijjā anusayaḥ avijjā pariyuṭṭhānam avijjā sayojanam avijjā nīvaraṇa no ca vata re vattabbe  atthi arahato aññāṇanti
translated: “Yes.”🔽“Now, is it true that there is no ignorance, no flood of ignorance, no yoke of ignorance, no latent tendency to ignorance, no covering of ignorance, no bondage of ignorance, no impediment of ignorance in an Arahant, and yet that it cannot be said that there is non-knowing of an Arahant?”

original: Atthi puthujjanassa aññāṇaṁ, atthi tassa avijjā avijjogho avijjāyogo avijjānusayo avijjāpariyuṭṭhānaṁ avijjāsaṁyojanaṁ avijjānīvaraṇanti?
analyzed: atthi puthujjanassa aññāṇa atthi tassa avijjā avijjā oghaḥ avijjā yogaḥ avijjā anusayaḥ avijjā pariyuṭṭhānam avijjā sayojanam avijjā nīvaraṇanti
translated: “Is there non-knowing of an ordinary man, and is there ignorance, a flood of ignorance, a yoke of ignorance, a latent tendency to ignorance, a covering of ignorance, a bondage of ignorance, an impediment of ignorance in an ordinary man?”
“Yes.”

original: Atthi arahato aññāṇaṁ, atthi tassa avijjā avijjogho avijjāyogo avijjānusayo avijjāpariyuṭṭhānaṁ avijjāsaṁyojanaṁ avijjānīvaraṇanti?
analyzed: atthi arahataḥ aññāṇa atthi tassa avijjā avijjā oghaḥ avijjā yogaḥ avijjā anusayaḥ avijjā pariyuṭṭhānam avijjā sayojanam avijjā nīvaraṇanti
translated: Is there any unknowing of an Arahant, is there any ignorance, ignorance-flood, ignorance-clinging, ignorance-underlying-tendency, ignorance-obsession, ignorance-bond, ignorance-hindrance of him?
“That is not so.”

original: Atthi arahato aññāṇaṁ, natthi tassa avijjā avijjogho avijjāyogo avijjānusayo avijjāpariyuṭṭhānaṁ avijjāsaṁyojanaṁ avijjānīvaraṇanti?
analyzed: atthi arahataḥ aññāṇa natthi tassa avijjā avijjā oghaḥ avijjā yogaḥ avijjā anusayaḥ avijjā pariyuṭṭhānam avijjā sayojanam avijjā nīvaraṇanti
translated: Is there any unknowing of an Arahant, is there no ignorance, ignorance-flood, ignorance-clinging, ignorance-underlying-tendency, ignorance-obsession, ignorance-bond, ignorance-hindrance of him?
“Yes.”

original: Atthi puthujjanassa aññāṇaṁ, natthi tassa avijjā avijjogho avijjāyogo avijjānusayo avijjāpariyuṭṭhānaṁ avijjāsaṁyojanaṁ avijjānīvaraṇanti?
analyzed: atthi puthujjanassa aññāṇa natthi tassa avijjā avijjā oghaḥ avijjā yogaḥ avijjā anusayaḥ avijjā pariyuṭṭhānam avijjā sayojanam avijjā nīvaraṇanti
translated: Is there any unknowing of an ordinary man, is there no ignorance, ignorance-flood, ignorance-clinging, ignorance-underlying-tendency, ignorance-obsession, ignorance-bond, ignorance-hindrance of him?
“That is not so.”
“Is there any unknowing of an Arahant?”
“Yes.”

original: Arahā aññāṇapakato pāṇaṁ haneyya, adinnaṁ ādiyeyya, musā bhaṇeyya, pisuṇaṁ bhaṇeyya,
analyzed: arahā aññāṇa pakataḥ pāṇam haneyya adinnam ādiyeyya musā bhaṇeyya pisuṇam bhaṇeyya
translated: “Would an Arahant, being unknowing, kill living beings, take what is not given, tell lies, speak maliciously,

original: pharusaṁ bhaṇeyya, samphaṁ palapeyya, sandhiṁ chindeyya, nillopaṁ hareyya, ekāgāriyaṁ
analyzed: pharusam bhaṇeyya sampham palapeyya sandhim chindeyya nillopam hareyya ekāgāriya
translated: speak harshly, gossip, be divisive, be covetous, have ill will,🔽hold wrong view, break into houses, rob on the highways, ambush isolated places, commit burglary, commit adultery, or instigate others to do likewise?”

original: kareyya, paripanthe tiṭṭheyya, paradāraṁ gaccheyya, gāmaghātaṁ kareyya, nigamaghātaṁ kareyyāti?
analyzed: kareyya paripanthe tiṭṭheyya paradāram gaccheyya gāma ghātam kareyya nigama ghātam kareyya ati
translated: would make a path, would stand in the way, would go to another’s wife, would commit a village raid, would commit a town raid?”
“That is not so.”

original: Atthi puthujjanassa aññāṇaṁ, puthujjano aññāṇapakato pāṇaṁ haneyya, adinnaṁ ādiyeyya, musā bhaṇeyya …pe… gāmaghātaṁ kareyya, nigamaghātaṁ kareyyāti?
analyzed: atthi puthujjanassa aññāṇa puthujjanaḥ aññāṇa pakataḥ pāṇam haneyya adinnam ādiyeyya musā bhaṇeyya pe gāma ghātam kareyya nigama ghātam kareyya ati
translated: “Is there ignorance of the ordinary person, and is the ordinary person corrupted by ignorance, and would the ordinary person kill living beings, take what is not given, tell lies … commit a village raid, commit a town raid?”
“Yes.”

original: Atthi arahato aññāṇaṁ, arahā aññāṇapakato pāṇaṁ haneyya, adinnaṁ ādiyeyya …pe… gāmaghātaṁ kareyya, nigamaghātaṁ kareyyāti?
analyzed: atthi arahataḥ aññāṇa arahā aññāṇa pakataḥ pāṇam haneyya adinnam ādiyeyya pe gāma ghātam kareyya nigama ghātam kareyya ati
translated: “Is there ignorance of the perfected one, and is the perfected one corrupted by ignorance, and would the perfected one kill living beings, take what is not given … commit a village raid, commit a town raid?”
“That is not so.”

original: Atthi arahato aññāṇaṁ, na ca arahā aññāṇapakato pāṇaṁ haneyya, adinnaṁ ādiyeyya …pe… gāmaghātaṁ kareyya, nigamaghātaṁ kareyyāti?
analyzed: atthi arahataḥ aññāṇa na ca arahā aññāṇa pakataḥ pāṇam haneyya adinnam ādiyeyya pe gāma ghātam kareyya nigama ghātam kareyya ati
translated: “Is there ignorance of the perfected one, but the perfected one is not corrupted by ignorance, and would the perfected one not kill living beings, not take what is not given … not commit a village raid, not commit a town raid?”
“Yes.”

original: Atthi puthujjanassa aññāṇaṁ, na ca puthujjano aññāṇapakato pāṇaṁ haneyya, adinnaṁ ādiyeyya …pe… gāmaghātaṁ kareyya, nigamaghātaṁ kareyyāti?
analyzed: atthi puthujjanassa aññāṇa na ca puthujjanaḥ aññāṇa pakataḥ pāṇam haneyya adinnam ādiyeyya pe gāma ghātam kareyya nigama ghātam kareyya ati
translated: “Is there ignorance of the ordinary person, but the ordinary person is not corrupted by ignorance, and would the ordinary person not kill living beings, not take what is not given … not commit a village raid, not commit a town raid?”🔽“Yes.”
“That’s not what I said.”
“Is there anything that an arahant doesn’t know?”
“Yes.”

original: Atthi arahato satthari aññāṇaṁ, dhamme aññāṇaṁ, saṅghe aññāṇaṁ, sikkhāya aññāṇaṁ,
analyzed: atthi arahato satthari aññāṇa dhamme aññāṇa saṅghe aññāṇa sikkhāya aññāṇa
translated: “Is there anything that an arahant doesn’t know concerning the Teacher, the Teaching, the Sangha, the training,

original: pubbante aññāṇaṁ, aparante aññāṇaṁ, pubbantāparante aññāṇaṁ, idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti?
analyzed: pubbante aññāṇa aparante aññāṇa pubbanta aparante aññāṇa idappaccaya tā paṭicca samuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti
translated: the past, the future, the past and future, or the present condition of things that arise in dependence on a specific cause?”
“That’s not what I said.”

original: Natthi arahato satthari aññāṇaṁ, dhamme aññāṇaṁ, saṅghe aññāṇaṁ, sikkhāya aññāṇaṁ,
analyzed: natthi arahato satthari aññāṇa dhamme aññāṇa saṅghe aññāṇa sikkhāya aññāṇa
translated: “Is there anything that an arahant does know concerning the Teacher, the Teaching, the Sangha, the training,

original: pubbante aññāṇaṁ, aparante aññāṇaṁ, pubbantāparante aññāṇaṁ, idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti?
analyzed: pubbante aññāṇa aparante aññāṇa pubbanta aparante aññāṇa idappaccaya tā paṭicca samuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti
translated: the past, the future, the past and future, or the present condition of things that arise in dependence on a specific cause?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci natthi arahato satthari aññāṇaṁ, dhamme aññāṇaṁ, saṅghe aññāṇaṁ …pe… idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇaṁ, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: āmantā  hañci natthi arahato satthari aññāṇa dhamme aññāṇa saṅghe aññāṇam pe idappaccaya tā paṭicca samuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇa no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “Yes.”🔽“Well, if there’s anything that an arahant doesn’t know concerning the Teacher, the Teaching, the Sangha, the training,🔽the past, the future, the past and future, or the present condition of things that arise in dependence on a specific cause, then you should say that there’s something that an arahant doesn’t know.🔽But if there’s nothing that an arahant doesn’t know concerning the Teacher, the Teaching, the Sangha, the training,

the past, the future, the past and future, or the present condition of things that arise in dependence on a specific cause, then you shouldn’t say that there’s something that an arahant doesn’t know.”

original: Atthi puthujjanassa aññāṇaṁ, atthi tassa satthari aññāṇaṁ, dhamme aññāṇaṁ, saṅghe aññāṇaṁ …pe… idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti?
analyzed: atthi puthujjanassa aññāṇa atthi tassa satthari aññāṇa dhamme aññāṇa saṅghe aññāṇam pe idappaccaya tā paṭicca samuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti
translated: Is there any unknowing of a worldling, is there any unknowing of his Teacher, Dhamma, Sangha … is there any unknowing of him regarding ideas that are causally produced by dependence?
“Yes.”

original: Atthi arahato aññāṇaṁ, atthi tassa satthari aññāṇaṁ, dhamme aññāṇaṁ, saṅghe aññāṇaṁ …pe… idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti?
analyzed: atthi arahataḥ aññāṇa atthi tassa satthari aññāṇa dhamme aññāṇa saṅghe aññāṇam pe idappaccaya tā paṭicca samuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti
translated: Is there any unknowing of an Arahant, is there any unknowing of his Teacher, Dhamma, Sangha … is there any unknowing of him regarding ideas that are causally produced by dependence?
“No, friend.”🔽

original: Atthi arahato aññāṇaṁ, natthi tassa satthari aññāṇaṁ, dhamme aññāṇaṁ, saṅghe aññāṇaṁ …pe… idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti?
analyzed: atthi arahataḥ aññāṇa natthi tassa satthari aññāṇa dhamme aññāṇa saṅghe aññāṇam pe idappaccaya tā paṭicca samuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti
translated: Is there any unknowing of an Arahant, is there any unknowing of his Teacher, Dhamma, Sangha … is there any unknowing of him regarding ideas that are causally produced by dependence?
“Yes.”

original: Atthi puthujjanassa aññāṇaṁ, natthi tassa satthari aññāṇaṁ, dhamme aññāṇaṁ, saṅghe aññāṇaṁ …pe… idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti?
analyzed: atthi puthujjanassa aññāṇa natthi tassa satthari aññāṇa dhamme aññāṇa saṅghe aññāṇam pe idappaccaya tā paṭicca samuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti
translated: Is there any unknowing of a worldling, is there any unknowing of his Teacher, Dhamma, Sangha … is there any unknowing of him regarding ideas that are causally produced by dependence?
“Then is it not the view of one who is not a recluse, the view of one who is not a brahmin?” “No.”
Is there any unknowing of an Arahant?
“Yes.”

original: Nanu arahato rāgo pahīno ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṁ anuppādadhammoti?
analyzed: nanu arahataḥ rāgaḥ pahīnaḥ ucchinna mūlo tālā vatthukataḥ anabhāvaṅkataḥ āyatim an uppāda dhammo ti
translated: “Isn’t it the case that a perfected one has abandoned passion, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it is no longer subject to future arising?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci arahato rāgo pahīno ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṁ anuppādadhammo, no ca vata re vattabbe—🔽“atthi arahato aññāṇan”ti.
analyzed: āmantā  hañci arahataḥ rāgaḥ pahīnaḥ ucchinna mūlo tālā vatthukataḥ anabhāvaṅkataḥ āyatim an uppāda dhammo no ca vata re vattabbe  atthi arahato aññāṇanti
translated: “Yes.”🔽“Then it is not the case that ‘A perfected one has a kind of knowledge that ‘I know that I will not return to that state.’”
“Is it the case that a perfected one has a kind of knowledge that ‘I know that I will not return to that state’?”

analyzed: āmantā  nanu arahataḥ dosaḥ pahīnaḥ pe  mohaḥ pahīnaḥ pe
translated: “Yes.”🔽“Isn’t it the case that a perfected one has abandoned aversion, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it is no longer subject to future arising?”

original: anottappaṁ pahīnaṁ ucchinnamūlaṁ tālāvatthukataṁ anabhāvaṅkataṁ āyatiṁ anuppādadhammanti?🔽Āmantā.
analyzed: an uttappam pahīnam ucchinna mūlam tālāvatthukatam anabhāvaṅkatam āyatim an uppāda dhammanti  āmantā
translated: “Isn’t it the case that a perfected one has abandoned delusion, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it is no longer subject to future arising?”🔽“Isn’t it the case that a perfected one has abandoned lack of conscience, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it is no longer subject to future arising?”

original: Hañci arahato anottappaṁ pahīnaṁ ucchinnamūlaṁ tālāvatthukataṁ anabhāvaṅkataṁ āyatiṁ anuppādadhammaṁ, no ca vata re vattabbe—🔽“atthi arahato aññāṇan”ti.
analyzed: hañci arahataḥ anottappam pahīnam ucchinna mūlam tālāvatthukatam anabhāvaṅkatam āyatim an uppāda dhamma no ca vata re vattabbe  atthi arahato aññāṇanti
translated: “Then it is not the case that ‘A perfected one has a kind of knowledge that ‘I know that I will not return to that state.’”
“Is it the case that a perfected one has a kind of knowledge that ‘I know that I will not return to that state’?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: nanu arahataḥ rāga pahānāya maggaḥ bhāvito pe
translated: “Isn’t it the case that a perfected one has developed the path to abandoning passion …
and has developed the factors for Awakening?”
“Yes.”

original: Hañci arahato rāgappahānāya bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: hañci arahataḥ rāga pahānāya bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: But it would not be right to say that the monk has any ignorance.

analyzed: atthi arahato aññāṇanti  atthi arahato aññāṇanti
translated: “Does the monk have any ignorance?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: nanu arahataḥ dosa pahānāya pe  moha ppahānāya pe
translated: “Has the monk developed the path for the sake of abandoning ill will …🔽for the sake of abandoning confusion …
for the sake of abandoning lack of conscience …
for the sake of abandoning lack of shame?
“Yes.”🔽“Has the monk developed the factors of awakening for the sake of abandoning lack of shame?

original: Hañci arahato anottappapahānāya bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: hañci arahataḥ anottappa pahānāya bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: But it would not be right to say that the monk has any ignorance.

analyzed: atthi arahato aññāṇanti  atthi arahato aññāṇanti
translated: “Does the monk have any ignorance?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: nanu arahā vīta rāgaḥ vīta dosaḥ vīta mohaḥ
translated: “Has the monk abandoned sensual desire, abandoned ill will, abandoned confusion …
and realized the ending of defilements?”
“Yes.”
“Has the monk abandoned sensual desire …🔽and realized the ending of defilements?

original: sacchikātabbaṁ sacchikataṁ, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: sacchikātabbam sacchikata no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: But it would not be right to say that the monk has any ignorance.

analyzed: atthi arahato aññāṇanti  atthi arahato aññāṇanti
translated: “Does the monk have any ignorance?”

original: Sadhammakusalassa arahato atthi aññāṇaṁ, paradhammakusalassa arahato natthi aññāṇanti.
analyzed: sadhamma kusalassa arahataḥ atthi aññāṇa para dhamma kusalassa arahataḥ natthi aññāṇanti
translated: “The monk who is skilled in the true Teaching has ignorance, but the monk who is skilled in the affairs of others has no ignorance.”
Is there anything that is not known to a perfected one who is skilled in his own Dhamma?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: para dhamma kusalassa arahataḥ atthi aññāṇanti
translated: “Is there anything that is not known to a perfected one who is skilled in the Dhamma of others?”
“That can’t be said.”

analyzed: para dhamma kusalassa arahataḥ natthi aññāṇanti
translated: “Is there anything that is not known to a perfected one who is skilled in the Dhamma of others?”
“Yes.”
“Is there anything that is not known to a perfected one who is skilled in his own Dhamma?”
“That can’t be said.”

original: Sadhammakusalassa arahato rāgo pahīno, atthi tassa aññāṇanti?
analyzed: sadhamma kusalassa arahataḥ rāgaḥ pahīnaḥ atthi tassa aññāṇam ti
translated: “Is there anything that is not known to a perfected one who is skilled in his own Dhamma, but whose passion is abandoned, that is not known to him?”
“Yes.”

original: Paradhammakusalassa arahato rāgo pahīno, atthi tassa aññāṇanti?
analyzed: para dhamma kusalassa arahataḥ rāgaḥ pahīnaḥ atthi tassa aññāṇam ti
translated: “Is there anything that is not known to a perfected one who is skilled in the Dhamma of others, but whose passion is abandoned, that is not known to him?”
“That can’t be said.”

analyzed: sadhamma kusalassa arahataḥ doso pahīno pe
translated: “Is there anything that is not known to a perfected one who is skilled in his own Dhamma, but whose hate is abandoned …
but whose delusion is abandoned …
but whose lack of conscience is abandoned, that is not known to him?”
“Yes.”

original: Paradhammakusalassa arahato anottappaṁ pahīnaṁ, atthi tassa aññāṇanti?
analyzed: para dhamma kusalassa arahataḥ anottappam pahīna atthi tassa aññāṇanti
translated: “Is there anything that is not known to a perfected one who is skilled in the Dhamma of others, but whose lack of conscience is abandoned, that is not known to him?”
“That can’t be said.”🔽“Is there anything that is not known to a perfected one who is skilled in his own Dhamma, but whose path for the abandonment of passion is developed …

analyzed: sadhamma kusalassa arahataḥ rāga ppahānāya maggaḥ bhāvito pe
translated: “The path to the abandoning of lust that was developed by the monk Saṅgāmaji, who had skill in the fundamentals of the spiritual life, was developed by him for the purification of beings … for the overcoming of sorrow and lamentation, for the passing away of pain and dejection, for the attainment of the true way, for the realization of Nibbāna.”
Are the factors of awakening developed, and is there a further state that is to be known by him?”
“Yes.”

original: Paradhammakusalassa arahato rāgappahānāya bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā, atthi tassa aññāṇanti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe….🔽Sadhammakusalassa arahato dosappahānāya …pe…🔽mohappahānāya …pe…
analyzed: para dhamma kusalassa arahataḥ rāga ppahānāya bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā atthi tassa aññāṇanti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe  sa dhamma kusalassa arahataḥ dosa ppahānāya pe  moha ppahānāya pe
translated: “Is the path developed by a perfected one who is skilled in another’s thoughts for the fading away of passion …🔽for the fading away of aversion …🔽for the fading away of delusion …
for the fading away of fear …
Are the factors of awakening developed, and is there a further state that is to be known by him?”
“Yes.”🔽“Is the path developed by a perfected one who is skilled in his own thoughts for the fading away of fear …

original: Paradhammakusalassa arahato anottappapahānāya bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā, atthi tassa aññāṇanti?
analyzed: para dhamma kusalassa arahataḥ anottappa pahānāya bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā atthi tassa aññāṇanti
translated: Are the factors of awakening developed, and is there a further state that is to be known by him?”

“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye faculty … in the mind faculty … in the ear … in the nose … in the tongue … in the body … in the form … in the sound … “Yes.”

original: Paradhammakusalassa arahato rāgo pahīno, natthi tassa aññāṇanti?
analyzed: para dhamma kusalassa arahataḥ rāgaḥ pahīnaḥ natthi tassa aññāṇaṃ ti
translated: Is it that for one who is skilled in the Dhamma of others, who is an Arahant, passion is abandoned, but there is no knowledge of his having abandoned it?”
“Yes.”

original: Sadhammakusalassa arahato rāgo pahīno, natthi tassa aññāṇanti?
analyzed: sadhamma kusalassa arahataḥ rāgaḥ pahīnaḥ natthi tassa aññāṇaṃ ti
translated: “Is it that for one who is skilled in the Dhamma of himself, who is an Arahant, passion is abandoned, but there is no knowledge of his having abandoned it?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: para dhamma kusalassa arahataḥ doso pahīno pe
translated: “Is it that for one who is skilled in the Dhamma of others, who is an Arahant, aversion is abandoned …
delusion is abandoned …
conscientiousness is abandoned, but there is no knowledge of his having abandoned it?”
“Yes.”

original: Sadhammakusalassa arahato anottappaṁ pahīnaṁ, natthi tassa aññāṇanti?
analyzed: sadhamma kusalassa arahataḥ anottappam natthi tassa aññāṇanti
translated: “Is it that for one who is skilled in the Dhamma of himself, who is an Arahant, conscientiousness is abandoned, but there is no knowledge of his having abandoned it?”
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye sense-sphere and in the mind-object sense-sphere?” …

analyzed: para dhamma kusalassa arahataḥ rāga ppahānāya maggaḥ bhāvito pe
translated: “Is it that for one who is skilled in the Dhamma of others, who is an Arahant, the path is developed for the abandoning of passion …
the factors of enlightenment are developed …

analyzed: dosa pahānāya moha ppahānāya pe  anottappa pahānāya maggaḥ bhāvito pe
translated: for the abandoning of aversion … for the abandoning of delusion …
for the abandoning of unconscientiousness, but there is no knowledge of his having developed it?”
“Yes.”

original: Sadhammakusalassa arahato anottappapahānāya bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā, natthi tassa aññāṇanti?
analyzed: sadhamma kusalassa arahataḥ anottappa pahānāya bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā natthi tassa aññāṇanti
translated: “Is it that for one who is skilled in the Dhamma of himself, who is an Arahant, the factors of enlightenment are developed for the abandoning of unconscientiousness, but there is no knowledge of his having developed them?”

ear … in the nose … in the tongue … in the body … in the mind-consciousness element … in

analyzed: para dhamma kusalaḥ arahā vīta rāgaḥ vīta dosaḥ vīta moho pe
translated: Is the one who is skilled in another’s thoughts, the perfected one, the one who is free from lust, free from hate, free from delusion …
and has realized what can be realized, is there anything that he does not know?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: sa dhamma kusalaḥ arahā vīta rāgaḥ vīta dosaḥ vīta moho pe
translated: “Is the one who is skilled in his own thoughts, the perfected one, the one who is free from lust, free from hate, free from delusion …
and has realized what can be realized, is there anything that he does not know?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …
“Is there anything that the perfected one does not know?”
“Yes.”
“Has it not been said by the Blessed One:

original: “jānatohaṁ, bhikkhave, passato āsavānaṁ khayaṁ vadāmi, no ajānato no apassato.
analyzed: jānataḥ ha bhikkhave passataḥ āsavānam khayam vadāmi no a jānataḥ no a passataḥ
translated: ‘Bhikkhus, I say that knowledge and vision are for one who knows and sees, not for one who does not know and does not see.

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, jānato kiṁ passato āsavānaṁ khayo hoti?🔽‘Iti rūpaṁ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo, iti vedanā …pe…
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave jānataḥ kim passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti  iti rūpa iti rūpassa samudayaḥ iti rūpassa atthaṅgamaḥ iti vedanā pe
translated: And what does one who knows and sees know and see that knowledge and vision are for one who knows and sees, not for one who does not know and does not see?🔽“‘This is suffering,’ bhikkhus, is for one who knows and sees, not for one who does not know and does not see.
‘This is the origin of suffering’ …
‘This is the cessation of suffering’ …

original: iti viññāṇaṁ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti—
analyzed: iti viññāṇaḥ iti viññāṇassa samudayaḥ iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamaḥ ti
translated: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering’ is for one who knows and sees, not for one who does not know and does not see.

original: evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, jānato evaṁ passato āsavānaṁ khayo hotī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave jānataḥ evam passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti iti
translated: It is for one who knows and sees in this way that the destruction of the taints occurs.”
“Is there such a suttanta?”
“Yes.”

original: Tena hi na vattabbaṁ—🔽“atthi arahato aññāṇan”ti.
analyzed: tena hi na vattabba  atthi arahato aññāṇanti
translated: “In that case, you should not say:🔽‘There is something that the perfected one does not know or see.’
“Is there something that the perfected one does not know or see?”
“Yes, there is.”
“But, friend, was it not said by the Blessed One:

original: “jānatohaṁ, bhikkhave, passato āsavānaṁ khayaṁ vadāmi, no ajānato no apassato.
analyzed: jānataḥ ha bhikkhave passataḥ āsavānam khayam vadāmi no a jānataḥ no a passataḥ
translated: ‘Bhikkhus, I say that knowledge and vision are not for one who is heedless, not for one who is not devoted to mental development, not for one who is not strenuous.

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, jānato kiṁ passato āsavānaṁ khayo hoti?
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave jānataḥ kim passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti
translated: But for one who is heedless, not devoted to mental development, and not strenuous, what knowledge and vision are there?
‘This is suffering’—

original: bhikkhave, jānato passato āsavānaṁ khayo hoti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti—🔽jānato passato āsavānaṁ khayo hoti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti—
analyzed: bhikkhave jānataḥ passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti ayam dukkha samudayo ti  jānataḥ passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti ayam dukkha nirodho ti
translated: there is knowledge and vision for one who knows and sees this. ‘This is the origin of suffering’—🔽there is knowledge and vision for one who knows and sees this. ‘This is the cessation of suffering’—

original: jānato passato āsavānaṁ khayo hoti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti—
analyzed: jānataḥ passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati
translated: there is knowledge and vision for one who knows and sees this. ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering’—
there is knowledge and vision for one who knows and sees this.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, jānato evaṁ passato āsavānaṁ khayo hotī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave jānataḥ evam passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti iti
translated: It is when one knows and sees thus that there is knowledge and vision for one who knows and sees.
“Is there a sutta to that effect?”
“Yes, there is.”

original: Tena hi na vattabbaṁ—🔽“atthi arahato aññāṇan”ti.
analyzed: tena hi na vattabba  atthi arahato aññāṇanti
translated: “In that case, you should not say:🔽‘There is something that the perfected one does not know or see.’
“Is there something that the perfected one does not know or see?”
“Yes, there is.”
Has it not been said by the Blessed One:

original: “sabbaṁ, bhikkhave, anabhijānaṁ aparijānaṁ avirājayaṁ appajahaṁ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya, sabbañca kho, bhikkhave, abhijānaṁ parijānaṁ virājayaṁ pajahaṁ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.
analyzed: bhikkhave an abhijānam a parijānam a virājayam appajaham abhabbaḥ dukkha kkhayāya sabbam ca kho bhikkhave abhijānam parijānam virājayam pajaham bhabbaḥ dukkha kkhayāya ati
translated: “Bhikkhus, without directly knowing and fully understanding all, without developing dispassion towards all, and without surmounting all, one is incapable of destroying suffering. But by directly knowing and fully understanding all, by developing dispassion towards all, and by surmounting all, one is capable of destroying suffering”?
“Is there a sutta that says this?”
“Yes.”

original: Tena hi na vattabbaṁ—🔽“atthi arahato aññāṇan”ti.
analyzed: tena hi na vattabba  atthi arahato aññāṇanti
translated: “Well then, you should not say so.”
“Is there anything that the Arahant does not know?”
“Yes.”
Has it not been said by the Blessed One:
“When one is perfected in vision,

analyzed: tayassu dhammā jahitāḥ bhavanti  sa kāya diṭṭhī vicikicchitañca
translated: Three things are abandoned:🔽Identity view, uncertainty, and whatever virtue and practices

analyzed: sīlabbatam vā api yat atthi kiñci
translated: are clung to as supreme;
And one is freed from four lower worlds,
And one cannot commit six wrong courses of action”?
“Is there a sutta that says this?”
“Yes.”

original: Tena hi na vattabbaṁ—🔽“atthi arahato aññāṇan”ti.
analyzed: tena hi na vattabba  atthi arahato aññāṇanti
translated: “Well then, you should not say so.”
“Is there anything that the Arahant does not know?”
“Yes.”
Has it not been said by the Blessed One:

original: “yasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye ariyasāvakassa virajaṁ vītamalaṁ dhammacakkhuṁ udapādi—
analyzed: yasmi bhikkhave samaye ariya sāvakassa virajam vīta malam dhamma cakkhum udapādi
translated: “When a noble disciple has seen clearly, in accordance with reality, the arising and passing away of the six sense fields,

original: ‘yaṁ kiñci samudayadhammaṁ sabbaṁ taṁ nirodhadhamman’ti, saha dassanuppādā, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa tīṇi saṁyojanāni pahīyanti—
analyzed: yam kiñci samudaya dhammam sabbam tam nirodha dhamman ti saha dassana uppādāḥ bhikkhave ariyasāvakassa tīṇi sayojanāni pahīyanti
translated: at that time three fetters are abandoned in them:

analyzed: sakkāya diṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbata parāmāsā ti
translated: personality view, doubt, and grasping at precepts and observances.”
Is there a discourse on this?
There is.
Well then, you shouldn’t say that
there is something that an perfected one doesn’t know.
You shouldn’t say that
there is something that a perfected one doesn’t know.

original: Nanu arahā itthipurisānaṁ nāmagottaṁ na jāneyya, maggāmaggaṁ na jāneyya, tiṇakaṭṭhavanappatīnaṁ nāmaṁ na jāneyyāti?
analyzed: nanu arahā itthi purisānam nāma gottam na jāneyya maggāmaggam na jāneyya tiṇa kaṭṭhavana ppatīnam nāmam na jāneyya ati
translated: But doesn’t a perfected one not know the names and clans of women and men, the roads and locations, and the names of grasses, trees, and forests?”
There is.

original: Hañci arahā itthipurisānaṁ nāmagottaṁ na jāneyya, maggāmaggaṁ na jāneyya, tiṇakaṭṭhavanappatīnaṁ nāmaṁ na jāneyya, tena vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: hañci arahā itthi purisānam nāma gottam na jāneyya maggāmaggam na jāneyya tiṇa kaṭṭhavana patīnam nāmam na jāneyya tena vata re vattabbe
translated: Well then, since a perfected one doesn’t know the names and clans of women and men, the roads and locations, and the names of grasses, trees, and forests, you should say that
there is something that a perfected one doesn’t know.”

original: Arahā itthipurisānaṁ nāmagottaṁ na jāneyya, maggāmaggaṁ na jāneyya, tiṇakaṭṭhavanappatīnaṁ nāmaṁ na jāneyyāti, atthi arahato aññāṇanti?
analyzed: arahā itthi purisānam nāma gottam na jāneyya maggāmaggam na jāneyya tiṇa kaṭṭhavana patīnam nāmam na jāneyya ati atthi arahataḥ aññāṇanti
translated: “Would an arahant not know the names and clans of women and men, not know what is the path and what is not the path, not know what is the Dhamma and what is not the Dhamma, not know what is the Teacher’s Dispensation and what is outside the Teacher’s Dispensation? “
“No.”🔽“Would an arahant not know the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning, or the fruit of arahantship?”

original: Arahā sotāpattiphalaṁ vā sakadāgāmiphalaṁ vā anāgāmiphalaṁ vā arahattaṁ vā na jāneyyāti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe….
analyzed: arahā sa utāpatti phalam vā sakadāgāmi phalam vā anāgāmi phalam vā arahattam vā na jāneyyāti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe
translated: Would an Arahant not know the fruit of Stream-Entry, or the fruit of Once-Returning, or the fruit of Non-Returning, or the fruit of Liberation?”🔽“Certainly not!” …
The Discussion of Non-knowing is finished.
